column4: hi is there a way to determine the installed programs on a non-booted install? LIke from a live-cd or something?
why is this a concern? just curious

my system died and I have an almost complete image of the dead drive, I would like to get a list of what I used to have installed from the image so that I won't spend three weeks trying to remmeber what I had installed
so you want to know installed "packages" not installed programs
yes, that's what I meant (to type) but obviously I said something different?
you said programs
sorry about that, I meant to say packages
there's a command you can run, and it will print a list of packages to a file on your desktop.
see above
thanks checking it now
that actualy looks pretty eays... i just tried the first part(to make the list) and it works.... i guess the only issue is getting the list from the borked hard drive, to the "virgin" hard drive
the challenge is getting this to work for a non booted partition..
oh.. yeah i dont think you're gonna have any luck there.. the system can't boot at all? even recovery mode?
nope it's in an eternal bootloop saying sectors are bad when I try
could you boot a live CD, chmod the drive, and run that command?
I have a full image on an external drive here atm
the sys partition has been mounted to /media/sys.. do you think I can do it this way?
how would I proceed with that? force mount the different partitions onto /bin /usr and such?
how would I do the chmod thing?
honestly, i'm really not 100% sure
could you give me some buzzowrds for google? I'm not having much luck finding anything
i think i'm actually thinkin gof chroot

shcherbak I'm assuming chroot is something I would not wnat to run from my current install but rathre from a livecd? Or could I just change the chroot for one instalnce of terminal and run dpkg in there?
i don't think it would really matter
